docs.title: Discord Legal Compliance Generator
docs.text: A Discord bot that automatically generates legal and compliance documents for Discord servers, including rules, privacy policies, terms of service, codes of conduct, staff SOPs, moderation guidelines, and appeal processes.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Multiple Document Types: Generate 7 different types of legal/compliance documents
  • Interactive Forms: User-friendly Discord modals for collecting information
  • Template-Based: Uses customizable markdown templates
  • Dual Command Support: Both slash commands (/generate) and message commands (!generate)
  • Markdown Output: Generates properly formatted markdown documents

docs.title: Supported Document Types
docs.text:
1. Server Rules - Community rules and guidelines
  2. Privacy Policy - Data collection and usage policies
  3. Terms of Service - User agreements and terms
  4. Code of Conduct - Expected behavior and community standards
  5. Staff SOPs - Standard Operating Procedures for staff members
  6. Moderation Guidelines - Moderation policies and procedures
  7. Appeal Process - Process for appealing moderation actions

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Install the bot - Follow the Installation Guide
  2. Configure - Set up your bot token and preferences - see Configuration
  3. Start generating - Use /generate or !generate in your Discord server

docs.title: Documentation
docs.text:
• Getting Started - Installation and setup instructions
  • Usage Guide - Complete command reference and examples
  • Customization - Customize templates and add new document types
  • API Reference - Developer documentation
  • Troubleshooting - Common issues and solutions

docs.title: Example Usage
docs.text:
# In Discord, type:
/generate rules
# or
!generate privacy_policy

The bot will guide you through an interactive form to collect the necessary information, then generate your document.

docs.title: Important Note
docs.text: This bot generates template-based documents. For legal matters, it's recommended to have documents reviewed by a legal professional.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: Common issues and solutions for the Discord Legal Compliance Generator bot.

docs.title: Bot Doesn't Connect
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Bot doesn't appear online in Discord - No startup messages in console - Connection errors in logs

Solutions:

  1. Check Bot Token: 

    # Verify .env file exists and has correct token
cat .env
    Ensure DISCORD_BOT_TOKEN is set correctly.

  2. Verify Token Validity:

  3. Go to Discord Developer Portal
  4. Check if token is still valid

  5. Reset token if needed and update .env

  6. Check Internet Connection:

  7. Ensure your server has internet access
  8. Check firewall settings

  9. Verify Discord API is accessible

  10. Review Logs: 

    # Check for specific error messages
# Common errors:
# - "401 Unauthorized" - Invalid token
# - "403 Forbidden" - Missing permissions
# - Connection timeout - Network issues

docs.title: Bot Connects But Immediately Disconnects
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Bot appears online briefly then goes offline - Repeated connection/disconnection cycles

Solutions:

  1. Check Bot Intents:
  2. Verify intents are enabled in Discord Developer Portal

  3. Ensure message_content intent is enabled if using message commands

  4. Review Error Logs:

  5. Check for exception errors in console

  6. Look for permission-related errors

  7. Verify Python Version: 

    python --version
# Should be 3.10 or higher

docs.title: Slash Commands Not Appearing
docs.text:
Symptoms: - /generate command doesn't show in Discord - Commands not in autocomplete

Solutions:

  1. Wait for Sync:
  2. Slash commands can take up to 1 hour to sync globally
  3. Restart Discord client

  4. Try in a server where bot was just added

  5. Check Bot Permissions:

  6. Verify bot has "Use Slash Commands" permission

  7. Ensure bot has "applications.commands" scope

  8. Force Command Sync: 

    # In bot.py, ensure setup_hook includes:
synced = await self.tree.sync()
logger.info(f"Synced {len(synced)} slash command(s)")

  9. Verify Command Registration:

  10. Check bot/commands/generate.py has @app_commands.command decorator
  11. Ensure cog is loaded in setup_hook()

docs.title: Commands Not Responding
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Bot doesn't respond to /generate or !generate - No error messages

Solutions:

  1. Check Bot Status:
  2. Verify bot is online (green status)

  3. Check bot is in the server/channel

  4. Verify Permissions:

  5. Bot needs "Send Messages" permission
  6. Check channel permissions

  7. Verify bot role has necessary permissions

  8. Check Command Prefix: 

    # Verify BOT_PREFIX in .env matches what you're using
# Default is "!"

  9. Review Bot Logs:

  10. Check for error messages
  11. Look for permission denied errors

docs.title: Form Modal Not Appearing
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Clicking document type button doesn't show form - Modal doesn't open

Solutions:

  1. Update Discord Client:
  2. Modals require recent Discord client version

  3. Update Discord to latest version

  4. Check Interaction Response:

  5. Ensure modal is sent before timeout

  6. Verify interaction.response.send_modal() is called

  7. Review Form Handler:

  8. Check form_handler.py for errors
  9. Verify modal is properly constructed

docs.title: Template Not Found Error
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Error: "Template not found for {document_type}" - FileNotFoundError in logs

Solutions:

  1. Verify Template Exists: 

    ls bot/templates/
# Should show all .md files

  2. Check Template Name:

  3. Template filename must match document type key
  4. Example: rules.md for document type "rules"

  5. Case-sensitive on some systems

  6. Verify Template Directory: 

    # Check TEMPLATES_DIR in config/config.py
# Should point to bot/templates/

docs.title: Variables Not Replacing
docs.text:
Symptoms: - {variable_name} appears literally in generated document - Placeholders not filled

Solutions:

  1. Check Variable Names:
  2. Variable names in template must match form data keys
  3. Case-sensitive matching

  4. Check for typos

  5. Verify Form Data: 

    # In form_handler.py, ensure form_data dictionary
# has keys matching template variables
form_data = {
    "server_name": server_name.value,  # Matches {server_name}
    # ...
}

  6. Check Template Encoding:

  7. Ensure template files are UTF-8 encoded
  8. Check for hidden characters

docs.title: Document Too Long
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Error about message length - Document truncated

Solutions:

  1. Automatic File Handling:
  2. Bot automatically sends long documents as files

  3. Check for .md file attachment

  4. Split Content:

  5. Break long documents into sections

  6. Use multiple messages if needed

  7. Template Optimization:

  8. Remove unnecessary content
  9. Use concise formatting

docs.title: Environment Variables Not Loading
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Bot token not found - Configuration errors

Solutions:

  1. Verify .env File:

ls -la .env

# Verify format (no spaces around =)

BOT_PREFIX=!

  2. Check python-dotenv: 

    pip install python-dotenv

  3. Verify Loading:

from dotenv import load_dotenv
load_dotenv()

docs.title: Bot Prefix Not Working
docs.text:
Symptoms: - !generate doesn't work - Wrong prefix expected

Solutions:

  1. Check .env File: 

    BOT_PREFIX=!
# Or your preferred prefix

  2. Restart Bot:

  3. Configuration loads on startup

  4. Restart after changing prefix

  5. Verify Message Content Intent:

  6. Required for message commands
  7. Enable in Discord Developer Portal

docs.title: Missing Permissions Error
docs.text:
Symptoms: - "Missing Permissions" error - Bot can't send messages

Solutions:

  1. Check Bot Permissions:
  2. Server Settings → Roles → Bot Role

  3. Enable: Send Messages, Embed Links, Attach Files

  4. Channel Permissions:

  5. Right-click channel → Edit Channel → Permissions

  6. Ensure bot role has necessary permissions

  7. Verify Invite URL:

  8. Re-invite bot with correct permissions
  9. Use OAuth2 URL Generator in Developer Portal

docs.title: Bot Slow to Respond
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Commands take long to process - Delayed responses

Solutions:

  1. Check System Resources:
  2. Monitor CPU and memory usage

  3. Check for resource constraints

  4. Review Logging:

  5. Excessive logging can slow bot

  6. Adjust log level if needed

  7. Template Size:

  8. Large templates may slow generation
  9. Optimize template content

docs.title: High Memory Usage
docs.text:
Symptoms: - Bot uses excessive memory - System slowdown

Solutions:

  1. Check Active Forms:
  2. active_forms dictionary stores form data
  3. Forms timeout after 5 minutes

  4. Consider reducing timeout if needed

  5. Template Caching:

  6. Templates are loaded on-demand
  7. Consider caching for frequently used templates

docs.title: LegalComplianceBot
docs.text:
Main bot class extending commands.Bot.

Location: bot/bot.py

Key Methods:

  • setup_hook() - Loads cogs and syncs slash commands
  • on_ready() - Called when bot connects
  • on_command_error() - Handles command errors

Example:

from bot.bot import create_bot

bot = create_bot()
bot.run(DISCORD_BOT_TOKEN)

docs.title: DocumentGenerator
docs.text:
Handles template loading and document generation.

Location: bot/handlers/document_generator.py

Methods:

docs.title: load_template(document_type: str) -> str
docs.text:
Loads a template file for the given document type.

Parameters: - document_type (str): Type of document (e.g., "rules", "privacy_policy")

Returns: - str: Template content as string

Raises: - FileNotFoundError: If template file doesn't exist

Example:

from bot.handlers.document_generator import DocumentGenerator

generator = DocumentGenerator()
template = generator.load_template("rules")

docs.title: generate_document(document_type: str, variables: Dict[str, Any]) -> str
docs.text:
Generates a document by replacing template variables.

Parameters: - document_type (str): Type of document to generate - variables (Dict[str, Any]): Dictionary of variable names and values

Returns: - str: Generated markdown document

Example:

variables = {
    "server_name": "My Server",
    "contact_info": "admin@example.com",
    "rules": ["Rule 1", "Rule 2"]
}

document = generator.generate_document("rules", variables)

docs.text:
Returns list of available document types based on template files.

Returns: - list: List of document type strings

docs.title: config.py
docs.text:
Configuration constants and settings.

Constants:

  • DISCORD_BOT_TOKEN (str): Bot token from environment
  • BOT_PREFIX (str): Command prefix for message commands
  • DOCUMENT_TYPES (Dict[str, str]): Mapping of document type keys to display names

Example:

from config.config import DOCUMENT_TYPES, TEMPLATES_DIR

# Access document types
for key, name in DOCUMENT_TYPES.items():
    print(f"{key}: {name}")

# Get templates directory

docs.title: Template Format
docs.text:
Templates use placeholder variables in format {variable_name}:

# {server_name} - Server Rules

{contact_info}

## Rules
{formatted_rules}

docs.title: Variable Replacement
docs.text:
Variables are replaced using string substitution:

template = "# {server_name} Rules"
document = template.replace("{server_name}", "My Server")
# Result: "# My Server Rules"

docs.title: List Formatting
docs.text:
Arrays are automatically formatted as markdown lists:

rules = ["Rule 1", "Rule 2", "Rule 3"]
formatted = "\n".join(f"- {rule}" for rule in rules)
# Result: "- Rule 1\n- Rule 2\n- Rule 3"

docs.title: Adding New Commands
docs.text:
Create a new command file in bot/commands/:

from discord.ext import commands

class MyCommands(commands.Cog):
    def __init__(self, bot):
        self.bot = bot

    @commands.command(name="mycommand")
    async def my_command(self, ctx):
        await ctx.send("Hello!")

    @app_commands.command(name="mycommand")
    async def my_slash_command(self, interaction: discord.Interaction):
        await interaction.response.send_message("Hello!")

async def setup(bot):
    await bot.add_cog(MyCommands(bot))

Load in bot/bot.py:

await self.load_extension("bot.commands.my_commands")

docs.title: Adding New Document Types
docs.text: Learn how to add custom document types to the bot.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Adding a new document type requires:

  1. Creating a template file
  2. Adding the document type to configuration
  3. Creating a form handler
  4. Testing the new document type

docs.title: Step 1: Create Template File
docs.text:
Create a new Markdown template in bot/templates/:

bot/templates/my_document_type.md

docs.title: Template Structure
docs.text:
Use placeholder variables that will be replaced with form data:

# {server_name} - My Custom Document

## Introduction

{introduction_text}

## Main Content

{main_content}

## Contact

{contact_info}

docs.title: Step 2: Update Configuration
docs.text:
Add your document type to config/config.py:

DOCUMENT_TYPES = {
    "rules": "Server Rules",
    "privacy_policy": "Privacy Policy",
    # ... existing types ...
    "my_document_type": "My Custom Document",  # Add your new type
}

The key (e.g., "my_document_type") must match your template filename (without .md).

docs.title: Step 3: Create Form Handler
docs.text: Add a modal form handler in bot/handlers/form_handler.py.

docs.title: Step 3a: Add Modal Method
docs.text:
Add a method to create your document's modal:

def _get_my_document_modal(self) -> discord.ui.Modal:
    """Modal for My Custom Document."""
    server_name = discord.ui.TextInput(
        label="Server Name",
        placeholder="Enter your server name",
        required=True,
        max_length=100
    )

    introduction_text = discord.ui.TextInput(
        label="Introduction Text",
        placeholder="Enter introduction",
        style=discord.TextStyle.paragraph,
        required=True,
        max_length=500
    )

    main_content = discord.ui.TextInput(
        label="Main Content",
        placeholder="Enter main content",
        style=discord.TextStyle.paragraph,
        required=True,
        max_length=2000
    )

    contact_info = discord.ui.TextInput(
        label="Contact Information",
        placeholder="Email or Discord username",
        required=False,
        max_length=200
    )

    async def callback(interaction: discord.Interaction):
        form_data = {
            "server_name": server_name.value,
            "introduction_text": introduction_text.value,
            "main_content": main_content.value,
            "contact_info": contact_info.value or "Contact server administrators"
        }
        await self._process_form(interaction, "my_document_type", form_data)

    modal = DynamicModal(title="Generate My Custom Document", callback_func=callback)
    modal.add_item(server_name)
    modal.add_item(introduction_text)
    modal.add_item(main_content)
    modal.add_item(contact_info)
    return modal

docs.title: Step 3b: Register the Modal
docs.text:
Update the _get_form_modal method to include your new document type:

def _get_form_modal(self, document_type: str) -> discord.ui.Modal:
    """Get the appropriate modal form for a document type."""
    modals = {
        "rules": self._get_rules_modal,
        "privacy_policy": self._get_privacy_policy_modal,
        # ... existing modals ...
        "my_document_type": self._get_my_document_modal,  # Add your modal
    }

    return modals.get(document_type, self._get_generic_modal)()

docs.text:
Update the get_document_type_embed method to include your new type:

docs.title: Step 4: Test Your New Document Type
docs.text:
1. Restart the bot
  2. Test the command: 
    /generate my_document_type
  3. Fill out the form and verify the generated document
  4. Check the template variables are replaced correctly

docs.title: Complete Example
docs.text: Here's a complete example of adding a "Community Guidelines" document type:

docs.title: 1. Template File (bot/templates/community_guidelines.md)
docs.text:
# {server_name} - Community Guidelines

## Welcome

{welcome_message}

## Guidelines

{guidelines}

## Enforcement

{enforcement_policy}

## Contact

{contact_info}

docs.title: 2. Configuration (config/config.py)
docs.text:
DOCUMENT_TYPES = {
    # ... existing types ...
    "community_guidelines": "Community Guidelines",
}

docs.title: 3. Form Handler (bot/handlers/form_handler.py)
docs.text:
def _get_community_guidelines_modal(self) -> discord.ui.Modal:
    """Modal for Community Guidelines."""
    server_name = discord.ui.TextInput(
        label="Server Name",
        placeholder="Enter your server name",
        required=True,
        max_length=100
    )

    welcome_message = discord.ui.TextInput(
        label="Welcome Message",
        placeholder="Welcome message for new members",
        style=discord.TextStyle.paragraph,
        required=True,
        max_length=500
    )

    guidelines = discord.ui.TextInput(
        label="Guidelines (one per line)",
        placeholder="Guideline 1\nGuideline 2\nGuideline 3",
        style=discord.TextStyle.paragraph,
        required=True,
        max_length=1500
    )

    enforcement_policy = discord.ui.TextInput(
        label="Enforcement Policy",
        placeholder="How guidelines are enforced",
        style=discord.TextStyle.paragraph,
        required=True,
        max_length=500
    )

    contact_info = discord.ui.TextInput(
        label="Contact Information",
        placeholder="Email or Discord username",
        required=False,
        max_length=200
    )

    async def callback(interaction: discord.Interaction):
        form_data = {
            "server_name": server_name.value,
            "welcome_message": welcome_message.value,
            "guidelines": [g.strip() for g in guidelines.value.split("\n") if g.strip()],
            "enforcement_policy": enforcement_policy.value,
            "contact_info": contact_info.value or "Contact server administrators"
        }
        await self._process_form(interaction, "community_guidelines", form_data)

    modal = DynamicModal(title="Generate Community Guidelines", callback_func=callback)
    modal.add_item(server_name)
    modal.add_item(welcome_message)
    modal.add_item(guidelines)
    modal.add_item(enforcement_policy)
    modal.add_item(contact_info)
    return modal

Update the modal registry:

modals = {
    # ... existing modals ...
    "community_guidelines": self._get_community_guidelines_modal,
}

docs.title: Handling Lists in Templates
docs.text:
If your form collects list data (like rules or guidelines), the DocumentGenerator automatically formats them. In your template, use:

{guidelines}  # Raw list (array)

Or format manually in the template:

## Guidelines

{formatted_guidelines}

The generator converts arrays to formatted markdown lists automatically.

docs.title: 1. Naming Conventions
docs.text:
• Use snake_case for document type keys: my_document_type
  • Use descriptive names: community_guidelines not doc1
  • Match template filename to document type key

docs.title: 2. Form Design
docs.text:
• Keep forms concise (Discord modals have limits)
  • Use appropriate input types (short vs paragraph)
  • Mark required fields clearly
  • Provide helpful placeholders

docs.title: 3. Template Design
docs.text:
• Use clear section headings
  • Include all form variables
  • Provide fallback text for optional fields
  • Test with various input lengths

docs.title: 4. Error Handling
docs.text:
The existing _process_form method handles errors, but you can add custom validation:

async def callback(interaction: discord.Interaction):
    # Custom validation
    if len(guidelines.value.split("\n")) < 3:
        await interaction.response.send_message(
            "Please provide at least 3 guidelines.",
            ephemeral=True
        )
        return

    form_data = {
        # ... form data ...
    }
    await self._process_form(interaction, "document_type", form_data)

docs.title: Document Type Not Appearing
docs.text:
Problem: New document type doesn't show in selection menu

Solution: - Verify it's in DOCUMENT_TYPES dictionary - Check get_document_type_embed includes it - Ensure DocumentTypeView has the button - Restart the bot

docs.title: Form Not Showing
docs.text:
Problem: Modal doesn't appear when selecting document type

Solution: - Check modal is registered in _get_form_modal - Verify method name matches - Check for syntax errors in modal method - Review bot logs for errors

docs.title: Variables Not Replacing
docs.text:
Problem: Template variables appear literally

Solution: - Ensure form data keys match template variables - Check variable names are exact (case-sensitive) - Verify template file encoding

docs.title: Template Not Found
docs.text:
Problem: Error says template file not found

Solution: - Verify template file exists in bot/templates/ - Check filename matches document type key - Ensure file has .md extension - Check file permissions

docs.title: Template Customization

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: This guide covers all configuration options for the Discord Legal Compliance Generator bot.

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text: The bot uses environment variables for configuration. These are stored in a .env file in the root directory.

docs.title: DISCORD_BOT_TOKEN
docs.text:
Your Discord bot token from the Discord Developer Portal.

DISCORD_BOT_TOKEN=your_bot_token_here

Security Warning

Never commit your .env file to version control. It's already included in .gitignore for your protection.

docs.title: BOT_PREFIX
docs.text:
The prefix for message commands (default: !).

BOT_PREFIX=!

Examples: - BOT_PREFIX=! - Use !generate for commands - BOT_PREFIX=. - Use .generate for commands - BOT_PREFIX=bot! - Use bot!generate for commands

docs.title: Configuration File
docs.text: The main configuration is managed in config/config.py. This file contains:

docs.title: Document Types
docs.text:
The available document types are defined in DOCUMENT_TYPES:

DOCUMENT_TYPES = {
    "rules": "Server Rules",
    "privacy_policy": "Privacy Policy",
    "terms_of_service": "Terms of Service",
    "code_of_conduct": "Code of Conduct",
    "staff_sops": "Staff SOPs",
    "moderation_guidelines": "Moderation Guidelines",
    "appeal_process": "Appeal Process",
}

To add or modify document types, edit this dictionary. See Adding New Document Types for detailed instructions.

docs.title: Template Directory
docs.text:
The template directory path is automatically configured:

TEMPLATES_DIR = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(os.path.dirname(__file__)), "bot", "templates")

Templates are stored in bot/templates/ as markdown files. See Template Customization for more information.

docs.title: Bot Permissions
docs.text: Ensure your bot has the following permissions in your Discord server:

docs.title: Required Permissions
docs.text:
• Send Messages - To send command responses and generated documents
  • Use Slash Commands - To register and respond to slash commands
  • Embed Links - To send rich embeds with document type selection
  • Attach Files - To send generated documents as markdown files

docs.title: Recommended Permissions
docs.text:
• Read Message History - To see previous messages in channels
  • Add Reactions - For better user experience (if you add reaction-based features)

docs.title: Bot Intents
docs.text:
The bot uses the following Discord intents (configured in bot/bot.py):

  • Default Intents - Standard bot functionality
  • Message Content Intent - Required to read message commands
  • Guilds Intent - To access server information

Intent Requirements

If you're using Discord.py 2.0+, message content intent must be enabled in the Discord Developer Portal under your bot's settings.

docs.title: Changing the Bot Prefix
docs.text:
To change the command prefix:

  1. Edit your .env file: 

    BOT_PREFIX=your_preferred_prefix

  2. Restart the bot

The new prefix will be active immediately after restart.

docs.title: Customizing Document Types
docs.text:
To add, remove, or modify document types:

  1. Edit config/config.py and update the DOCUMENT_TYPES dictionary
  2. Create or modify template files in bot/templates/
  3. Add form handlers in bot/handlers/form_handler.py (if adding new types)
  4. Restart the bot

See Adding New Document Types for a complete guide.

docs.title: Logging Configuration
docs.text:
Logging is configured in bot/bot.py. The default configuration:

  • Level: INFO
  • Format: %(asctime)s - %(name)s - %(levelname)s - %(message)s

To change logging level, edit bot/bot.py:

logging.basicConfig(
    level=logging.DEBUG,  # Change to DEBUG, WARNING, or ERROR
    format='%(asctime)s - %(name)s - %(levelname)s - %(message)s'
)

docs.title: Production Considerations
docs.text:
For production deployments:

  1. Use Environment Variables - Never hardcode tokens or secrets
  2. Enable Logging - Set up proper log rotation and monitoring
  3. Use Process Managers - Consider using systemd, pm2, or supervisord
  4. Monitor Resources - Set up alerts for bot downtime
  5. Backup Templates - Keep backups of your custom templates

docs.text:

  • Check out Troubleshooting for common issues

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: This guide will walk you through installing and setting up the Discord Legal Compliance Generator bot.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before you begin, ensure you have:

  • Python 3.10 or higher - Check your version with python --version or python3 --version
  • A Discord bot token - Get one from the Discord Developer Portal
  • Discord bot with appropriate permissions:
  • Send Messages
  • Use Slash Commands
  • Embed Links
  • Attach Files

docs.title: Step 1: Clone or Download the Repository
docs.text:
Clone the repository using Git:

git clone https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/discord-legal-compliance-generator.git
cd discord-legal-compliance-generator

Or download and extract the ZIP file from GitHub.

docs.title: Step 2: Install Dependencies
docs.text:
Install the required Python packages:

pip install -r requirements.txt

If you're using Python 3 specifically:

pip3 install -r requirements.txt

For a virtual environment (recommended):

# Create virtual environment
python -m venv venv

# Activate virtual environment
# On Windows:
venv\Scripts\activate
# On macOS/Linux:
source venv/bin/activate

# Install dependencies
pip install -r requirements.txt

docs.title: Step 3: Set Up Environment Variables
docs.text:
1. Copy the example environment file: 

    cp .env.example .env

  2. Edit the .env file and add your Discord bot token: 

    DISCORD_BOT_TOKEN=your_bot_token_here
BOT_PREFIX=!

Replace your_bot_token_here with your actual bot token from the Discord Developer Portal.

docs.title: Step 4: Get Your Discord Bot Token
docs.text:
1. Go to the Discord Developer Portal
  2. Click "New Application" and give it a name
  3. Go to the "Bot" section in the left sidebar
  4. Click "Add Bot" if you haven't already
  5. Under "Token", click "Reset Token" or "Copy" to get your bot token
  6. Paste this token into your .env file

Keep Your Token Secret

Never share your bot token publicly. If your token is exposed, reset it immediately in the Discord Developer Portal.

docs.title: Step 5: Invite Your Bot to Your Server
docs.text:
1. In the Discord Developer Portal, go to OAuth2 > URL Generator
  2. Select the following scopes:
  3. bot
  4. applications.commands
  5. Select the following bot permissions:
  6. Send Messages
  7. Use Slash Commands
  8. Embed Links
  9. Attach Files
  10. Copy the generated URL and open it in your browser
  11. Select your Discord server and authorize the bot

docs.title: Step 6: Run the Bot
docs.text:
Start the bot with:

python main.py

Or if using Python 3 specifically:

python3 main.py

You should see output indicating the bot has connected:

INFO - BotName#1234 has connected to Discord!
INFO - Bot is in X guild(s)
INFO - Synced X slash command(s)

docs.title: Verification
docs.text:
To verify the bot is working:

  1. Go to your Discord server where the bot is present
  2. Type /generate or !generate
  3. You should see a menu with document type options

If the bot doesn't respond, check:

  • The bot is online (green status indicator)
  • The bot has proper permissions in the channel
  • Your bot token is correct in the .env file
  • The bot has the applications.commands scope

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Configure additional settings in Configuration
  • Learn how to use commands in Usage Guide
  • Customize templates in Customization Guide

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: If you encounter issues during installation, see the Troubleshooting Guide for common solutions.

docs.title: Commands Reference
docs.text: Complete reference for all bot commands, including slash commands and message commands.

docs.title: Command Overview
docs.text:
The bot supports two types of commands:

  • Slash Commands - Modern Discord slash commands (e.g., /generate)
  • Message Commands - Traditional prefix-based commands (e.g., !generate)

Both command types provide the same functionality.

docs.title: Generate Command
docs.text: The main command for generating legal/compliance documents.

docs.title: Slash Command
docs.text: /generate [document_type]

docs.title: Message Command
docs.text:
!generate [document_type]

Or using your configured prefix:

<prefix>generate [document_type]

docs.title: document_type (optional)
docs.text:
The type of document to generate. If omitted, a selection menu will be displayed.

Available document types:

Type Display Name Description rules Server Rules Community rules and guidelines privacy_policy Privacy Policy Data collection and usage policies terms_of_service Terms of Service User agreements and terms code_of_conduct Code of Conduct Expected behavior and community standards staff_sops Staff SOPs Standard Operating Procedures for staff moderation_guidelines Moderation Guidelines Moderation policies and procedures appeal_process Appeal Process Process for appealing moderation actions

docs.title: Without Document Type
docs.text:
Shows a selection menu with all available document types:

/generate

or

!generate

docs.title: With Document Type
docs.text:
Directly starts the form for a specific document type:

/generate rules

/generate privacy_policy

!generate code_of_conduct

!generate staff_sops

docs.title: Autocomplete
docs.text: When using slash commands, the document_type parameter supports autocomplete. Start typing and Discord will suggest matching document types.

docs.title: Help Command
docs.text: Get help information about the bot.

docs.title: Slash Command
docs.text: /help

docs.title: Message Command
docs.text:
!help

Displays information about: - Available commands - How to use the bot - Supported document types - Quick examples

docs.title: Step 1: Initiate Command
docs.text: Type /generate or !generate in a channel where the bot has permissions.

docs.title: Step 2: Select Document Type
docs.text:
If you didn't specify a document type:

  1. A menu with buttons will appear
  2. Click a button to select a document type
  3. Or type the document type name directly in the command

docs.title: Step 3: Fill Out Form
docs.text:
An interactive modal form will appear with fields specific to the document type:

  • Server Name - Required for all document types
  • Document-Specific Fields - Varies by document type

docs.title: Step 4: Receive Document
docs.text:
After submitting the form:

  • Short documents (< 1900 characters) are sent as formatted markdown code blocks
  • Longer documents are sent as .md file attachments

docs.title: Document Type Forms
docs.text: Each document type has a customized form. Here's what each form collects:

docs.title: Server Rules
docs.text:
• Server Name (required)
  • Contact Information (optional)
  • Rules (required, one per line)
  • Consequences for Violations (optional)

docs.title: Privacy Policy
docs.text:
• Server Name (required)
  • Contact Email (optional)
  • Data Collected (required, one per line)
  • How Data is Used (required)

docs.title: Terms of Service
docs.text:
• Server Name (required)
  • Contact Information (optional)
  • Prohibited Activities (required, one per line)
  • User Obligations (required)

docs.title: Code of Conduct
docs.text:
• Server Name (required)
  • Expected Behavior (required, one per line)
  • Reporting Process (required)
  • Contact Information (optional)

docs.title: Staff SOPs
docs.text:
• Server Name (required)
  • Staff Roles (required, one per line)
  • Key Procedures (required, one per line)
  • Escalation Path (required)

docs.title: Moderation Guidelines
docs.text:
• Server Name (required)
  • Moderation Actions (required, one per line)
  • Warning System (required)
  • Ban Criteria (required)

docs.title: Appeal Process
docs.text:
• Server Name (required)
  • Appeal Requirements (required)
  • Review Process (required)
  • Timelines (required)
  • Contact Information (optional)

docs.title: Command Permissions
docs.text:
The bot requires the following permissions to function:

  • Send Messages - To respond to commands
  • Use Slash Commands - To register slash commands
  • Embed Links - To display selection menus
  • Attach Files - To send generated documents

docs.title: Ephemeral Responses
docs.text: Slash command responses are sent as ephemeral messages by default, meaning only you can see them. This keeps the channel clean.

docs.title: Message Commands
docs.text: Message command responses are visible to everyone in the channel.

docs.title: Timeouts
docs.text:
• Button views timeout after 5 minutes (300 seconds)
  • If a view times out, you'll need to run the command again

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
If an error occurs:

  • The bot will send an error message explaining what went wrong
  • Check the bot's console logs for detailed error information
  • See Troubleshooting for common issues

docs.title: Tips and Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Use Slash Commands - They provide autocomplete and better user experience
  2. Be Specific - Include the document type in your command to skip the selection menu
  3. Fill Forms Completely - Required fields are marked, but optional fields improve document quality
  4. Review Generated Documents - Always review and customize generated documents before using them
  5. Save Documents - Download or copy generated documents for your records

docs.text:

  • Learn about Customization
  • Check Troubleshooting if you encounter issues

docs.title: Usage Examples

Temporary Mute (1-24 hours)
Temporary Ban (1-7 days)
Permanent Ban
- Warning System: "Users receive 3 warnings before a temporary ban. Warnings expire after 30 days of good behavior." - Ban Criteria: "Permanent bans are issued for severe violations including harassment, illegal content, or repeated rule violations after multiple warnings."

docs.title: Setting Up Appeals
docs.text:
/generate appeal_process

Form Fields: - Server Name: "Community Server" - Appeal Requirements: "Include your Discord username, reason for ban, and explanation of why you should be unbanned." - Review Process: "Appeals are reviewed by a panel of 3 moderators. Majority vote determines the outcome." - Timelines: "Appeals are reviewed within 7 business days. You will receive a response via DM." - Contact Information: "Submit appeals to appeals@community.com or use the appeal form on our website."

docs.title: Using the Button Menu
docs.text:
1. Type /generate without specifying a document type
  2. A menu with buttons appears:
  3. 📋 Rules
  4. 🔒 Privacy
  5. 📜 ToS
  6. ✅ CoC
  7. 👥 SOPs
  8. ⚖️ Moderation
  9. 📝 Appeal
  10. Click the button for your desired document type
  11. Complete the form that appears

docs.title: 1. Prepare Your Information
docs.text: Before running the command, gather: - Your server name - Contact information - Specific rules, policies, or procedures - Any custom requirements

docs.title: 2. Review Generated Documents
docs.text: Always review and customize generated documents: - Check for accuracy - Add server-specific details - Ensure legal compliance (consult a lawyer for legal documents) - Format for your server's needs

docs.title: 3. Save Your Documents
docs.text:
• Download generated .md files
  • Store them in a secure location
  • Keep backups
  • Update them as your server evolves

docs.title: 4. Customize Templates
docs.text: For frequently used documents, consider customizing templates: - Edit files in bot/templates/ - Add your server's branding - Include standard clauses - See Template Customization

docs.title: Setting Up a New Server
docs.text:
1. Generate Server Rules
  2. Create Terms of Service
  3. Set up Privacy Policy
  4. Write Code of Conduct
  5. Create Moderation Guidelines
  6. Set up Appeal Process
  7. Generate Staff SOPs

docs.title: Updating Existing Documents
docs.text:
1. Generate a new version of the document
  2. Compare with your current document
  3. Merge changes as needed
  4. Update your server's documentation

docs.title: Bulk Generation
docs.text:
Generate all documents in sequence: 

/generate rules
/generate privacy_policy
/generate terms_of_service
/generate code_of_conduct
/generate moderation_guidelines
/generate appeal_process
/generate staff_sops

docs.title: Command Not Working
docs.text:
Problem: Bot doesn't respond to /generate

Solution: - Check bot is online - Verify bot has "Use Slash Commands" permission - Wait a few minutes for slash commands to sync - Try !generate as an alternative

docs.title: Form Not Appearing
docs.text:
Problem: Modal form doesn't show up

Solution: - Ensure you're using the latest Discord client - Check bot has proper permissions - Try using slash commands instead of message commands

docs.title: Document Too Long
docs.text:
Problem: Generated document exceeds Discord's message limit

Solution: - The bot automatically sends long documents as files - Download the .md file attachment - Open in a markdown editor for viewing
